moves.2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 g6 4. Bc4 Bg7 5. f3: And this is called the Lion's defense: Lion's Jaw. The e pawn double protected by the knight and f3 pawn. This mirrors the Saemisch in King's Indian games.
moves.5... Nc6: Continually playing the Pirc I have learn, from experience, it is not always best to castle when you can.
moves.6. Nge2 Nd7: I believe, considering the g2, f3, e4 pawn chain, the f6 knight had no future role on f6.
moves.7... Na5: The bishop is indeed misplaced, Furthermore the pawn chain restricts its scope
moves.8. Bb3: The bishop is doing nothing and there is no reason to take it
moves.8... O-O 9. Bg5: !? This seems like a attack coming from a Saemisch player
moves.10. Be3: This should have been his move in the first place
moves.10... Ne5: The knights are going to coordinate with one another! if white plays Qd2: I'll play (either N) Nc4!
moves.11... e6: I try to set up a trap
moves.16... Qe7: Getting out of the line of fire. Also, notice his next move could have been Bxc5
moves.17. Nb5: I spent a couple hours looking at this position. An hour on the gameknot analyse program and another hour or so via printed copy. I could have defended further by playing 16...Nf7 or 16...Rd8 But that would allow counter play along the a file with his rook and knight.
moves.19... b6 20. Nf4 g5: it was best to rid the knight on f4.
moves.22. Nec3 Bb7 23. gxf3 Rxf3 24. Kg1 Rxe3: This was a very bad trade. I look at the screen for 10 seconds and said to myself,"woo woo, take the rook. Better take the rook." Better was to capture the knight for free.
moves.31. Nxd5 Re2 32. Nxb6: And I made another blunder.  White had better endgame skills than I.
moves.32... Rf8: Instead of pawn chasin', I decide to make a mating net with my two rooks, pawns and my king.
moves.39. Rg6+ Kf7 40. Rxh6 Rf1+ 41. Kg5 Rg8+: I opted for a sideways mate

gameName: Dynamics of the Pirc: delayed Lion's Defence
